------=_NextPart_000_0000_01C9D4D8.28AA6590
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Cesar,
 
I've found many bottlenecks in the partitioning schema for various HyperNEAT
experiments. They migrate through the compute fabric, like constraints in
the Theory of Constraints. Some of these have to do with the specific
configuration of the CPU cores to GPU process cores relationships.  Many of
the static experiment configuration parameters really shouldn't be static at
all - the size of the data structures - the initial population size ...
 
For example, in one series of experiments, the GPU implementation actually
underperformed the CPU "gold" standard.  All others outperformed that
standard, some dramatically.  Why? This is the kind of phenomenon I hope to
explore through this project.
 
In other words, what is really needed to configure a series of HyperNEAT
experiments is ... HyperNEAT. Actually, we've been working on that
suggestion for about a year now.
 
Thanks for your interest, and keep watching.
 
Ken Lloyd
 


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Cesar
G. M.
Sent: Thursday, May 14, 2009 10:07 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT on CUDA





What are you planning to parallelize in CUDA? The bottleneck in most
of the experiments in neuroevolution is the fitness function, which is
very specific for each goal. I'd start parallelizing a particular set
of experiments than HyperNEAT alone.

Cesar

On Thu, May 14, 2009 at 12:34 PM, Ken Lloyd <kalloyd@wattsys.
<mailto:kalloyd%40wattsys.com> com> wrote:
>
>
> Ken,
>
> Currently, the project is based on David D'Ambrosio's HyperSharpNeat v2.0.
> That library will undergo some major changes to be compatible with CUDA,
but
> I will try to keep it backwardly compatible, if possible.  The objective
of
> the project is not to change the NEAT library, but is to explore issues of
> parallelism in implementing it on CUDA.
>
> The factory will heavily rely on the structure of the library to partition
> data and tasks.
>
> Ken Lloyd
>
> ________________________________
> From: neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
[mailto:neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com] On Behalf Of
> Kenneth Stanley
> Sent: Wednesday, May 13, 2009 9:51 PM
> To: neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
> Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT on CUDA
>
> Ken, that looks like an interesting project, thanks for sharing it. I was
> curious, is the C# implementation of HyperNEAT within the CUDA project
your
> own, or is it extended from David D'Ambrosio's HyperSharpNEAT package?
>
> ken
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Ken Lloyd"
<kalloyd@...> wrote:
>>
>> Hi everyone,
>>
>> I've started a small GPL C# demonstration program on SourceForge to show
>> how
>> a Factory Pattern might be used to generate and compile HyperNEAT on CUDA
>> (NVidia's Compute Unified Device Architecture). This is just a part-time
>> personal project (nights and weekends).
>>
>> http://sourceforge. <http://sourceforge.net/projects/hyperneat4cuda>
net/projects/hyperneat4cuda
>>
>> It will probably take me a couple of days to a week to get everything
>> uploaded. I've also blocked out a TeX paper to describe the concepts,
>> challenges and points of interest.
>>
>> Ken Lloyd
>>
>> ============================
>> Kenneth A. Lloyd
>> CEO - Director of Systems Science
>> Watt Systems Technologies Inc.
